item.p: fails to comply with an expedited preservation of data direction or contravenes the provisions of subsection (4); or

makes a false statement in an application referred to in subsection (6), is guilty of an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding R5 million or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or to both such fine and imprisonment.

section.heading: Disclosure of data direction

blockList.listIntroduction: Subject to sections 15(2), 16 and 17 of the Regulation of Interception of Communications and Provision of Communication-related information Act, 2002 (Act No. 70 of 2002), and subsection (4), a magistrate or judge of the High Court, may on written application by a member of a law enforcement agency, if it appears to the magistrate or judge, from information on oath or by way of affirmation that there are reasonable grounds for believing that a person or electronic communications service provider may receive, is in possession of, or is in control of data which is relevant to or which may afford evidence of, the commission or intended commission of—

item.p: an offence under Chapter 2 of this Act; or
any other offence in terms of the laws of the Republic which is or was committed by means of, or facilitated by the use of an article, issue a disclosure of data direction.

blockList.listIntroduction: An application contemplated in subsection (1) must—

item.p: contain the identity of the member of the law enforcement agency who applies for the disclosure of data direction;
identify the customer, if known, or the service or communication in respect of whom data is to be provided;
identify the person or electronic communications service provider to whom the disclosure of data direction must be addressed;
contain a description of the data which must be provided;
contain a description of the offence which has been or is being or will probably be committed; and
comply with any supplementary directives relating to applications for expedited disclosure of data issued by the Judges President of the respective Divisions of the High Court.

blockList.listIntroduction: Upon receipt of an application in terms of subsection (1), a magistrate or judge, must satisfy himself or herself—
that there are reasonable grounds for believing that—

item.p: an offence in terms of Chapter 2 of this Act; or

any other offence in terms of the laws of the Republic which is or was committed by means of, or facilitated by the use of an article, has been, is being or will probably be committed or that it is necessary to determine whether such an offence has been so committed; and
that it will be in the interests of justice if a disclosure of data direction is issued.

blockList.listIntroduction: The designated judge, may on request of an authority, court or tribunal of a foreign State, if it appears to the designated judge, from information on oath or by way of affirmation that there are reasonable grounds for believing that any person or electronic communications service provider in the Republic may receive, is in possession of, or is in control of data which is relevant to, or which may afford evidence of, the commission or intended commission of an offence—

item.p: similar to those contemplated in Chapter 2 of this Act; or

any other offence substantially similar to an offence recognised in the Republic which is or was committed by means of, or facilitated by the use of an article, in a foreign State, issue, subject to paragraph (b), a disclosure of data direction.

blockList.listIntroduction: The designated judge must, before a disclosure of data direction as contemplated in paragraph (a) is issued, inform the Cabinet member responsible for the administration of justice, in writing of the—

item.p: fact that he or she intends to issue a disclosure of data direction; and
reasons for such decision.

blockList.listIntroduction: A request contemplated in subsection (4) must—

item.p: identify the customer, if known, or the service or communication in respect of whom data is to be provided;
identify the person or electronic communications service provider to whom the disclosure of data direction must be addressed;
contain a description of the data which must be provided;
contain a description of the offence which has been or is being or will probably be committed; and
comply with any supplementary directives relating to applications for disclosure of data issued by the designated judge.

blockList.listIntroduction: Upon receipt of a request in terms of subsections (4), the designated judge must satisfy himself or herself—
that there are reasonable grounds for believing that an offence—

item.p: similar to those contemplated in Chapter 2 of this Act; or

substantially similar to an offence recognised in the Republic which is or was committed by means of, or facilitated by the use of an article, in the requesting foreign State, has been committed or that it is necessary to determine whether such an offence has been so committed and that an investigation in respect thereof is being conducted in the requesting foreign State;

blockList.listIntroduction: that the request, where applicable, is in accordance with—

item.p: any treaty, convention or other international agreement to which that foreign state and the Republic are parties; or
any agreement with any foreign State entered into in terms of section 65 of this Act; and
that it will be in the interests of justice if a disclosure of data direction is issued.

content.p: A disclosure of data direction must be in the prescribed form and must be served on the person or electronic communications service provider affected thereby, in the prescribed manner by a member of a law enforcement agency or in the case of subsection (4), a specifically designated member of a law enforcement agency.

blockList.listIntroduction: The disclosure of data direction—

item.p: must direct the person or electronic communications service provider to provide data identified in the direction to the extent as is set out in the direction to an identified member of the law enforcement agency;
must set out the period within which the data identified in paragraph (a) must be provided; and
may specify conditions or restrictions relating to the provision of data authorised therein.

content.p: A person or electronic communications service provider to whom a disclosure of data direction referred to in subsection (7) is addressed, may in writing apply to the magistrate or judge or the designated judge for an amendment or the cancellation of the direction concerned on the ground that he, she or it cannot timeously or in a reasonable fashion, comply with the direction.

blockList.listIntroduction: The magistrate or judge or the designated judge to whom an application is made in terms of subsection (9) must, as soon as possible after receipt thereof—

item.p: consider the application and may, for this purpose, order oral or written evidence to be adduced regarding any fact alleged in the application;
give a decision in respect of the application; and
if the application is successful, inform the law enforcement agency or authority, court or tribunal of a foreign State, of the outcome of the application.

blockList.listIntroduction: A person or an electronic communications service provider who—

item.p: fails to comply with a disclosure of data direction; or

makes a false statement in an application referred to in subsection (9), is guilty of an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding R5 million or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or to both such fine and imprisonment.

section.heading: Preservation of evidence direction

blockList.listIntroduction: A magistrate or judge of the High Court, may on written application by a member of a law enforcement agency, if it appears to the magistrate or judge, from information on oath or by way of affirmation that there are reasonable grounds for believing that any person or electronic communications service provider may receive, is in possession of, or is in control of an article—

item.p: relevant to;
which was used or may be used in;
for the purpose of or in connection with;
which has facilitated or may facilitate; or

blockList.listIntroduction: may afford evidence of, the commission or intended commission of—

item.p: an offence under Chapter 2 of this Act;
any other offence in terms of the laws of the Republic which is or was committed by means of, or facilitated by the use of an article; or

blockList.listIntroduction: an offence—

item.p: similar to those contemplated in Chapter 2 of this Act; or

any other offence substantially similar to an offence recognised in the Republic which is or was committed by means of, or facilitated by the use of an article, in a foreign State, issue a preservation of evidence direction.

content.p: A preservation of evidence direction must be in the prescribed form and must be served on the person or electronic communications service provider affected thereby, in the prescribed manner by a member of a law enforcement agency.

blockList.listIntroduction: The preservation of evidence direction must direct the person or electronic communications service provider, from the time of service of the direction, and for the time period specified in the direction, immediately—

item.p: to preserve the current status of;
not to deal in any manner with; or
to deal in a certain manner with, an article in order to preserve the integrity of the evidence.

content.p: Any person or electronic communications service provider who fails to comply with a preservation of evidence direction is guilty of an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding R5 million or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding 5 years or to both such fine and imprisonment.

A person or electronic communications service provider to whom a preservation of evidence direction referred to in subsection (1) is addressed, may in writing apply to a magistrate or judge of the High Court in whose area of jurisdiction the person or electronic communications service provider is situated for an amendment or the cancellation of the direction concerned on the ground that he, she or it cannot timeously or in a reasonable fashion, comply with the order.

blockList.listIntroduction: The magistrate or judge of the High Court to whom an application is made in terms of subsection (5) must, as soon as possible after receipt thereof—

item.p: consider the application and may, for this purpose, order oral or written evidence to be adduced regarding any fact alleged in the application;
give a decision in respect of the application; and
inform the applicant and law enforcement agency of the outcome of the application.

section.heading: Oral application for preservation of evidence direction

content.p: An application referred to in section 42(1), may be made orally by a member of a law enforcement agency, if he or she is of the opinion that it is not reasonably practicable, having regard to the urgency of the case or the existence of exceptional circumstances, to make a written application.

blockList.listIntroduction: An oral application referred to in subsection (1) must—

item.p: indicate the particulars of the urgency of the case or the other exceptional circumstances which, in the opinion of the member of the law enforcement agency, justify the making of an oral application; and
comply with any supplementary directives relating to oral applications issued by the Judges President of the respective Divisions of the High Court.

content.p: A magistrate or judge of the High Court may, upon an oral application made to him or her in terms of subsection (1), issue the preservation of evidence direction applied for.

blockList.listIntroduction: A preservation of evidence direction may only be issued under subsection (3) —
if the magistrate or judge of the High Court concerned is satisfied, on the facts alleged in the oral application concerned, that—

item.p: there are reasonable grounds to believe that a preservation of evidence direction applied for could be issued;
a preservation of evidence direction is necessary immediately in order to preserve the integrity of the evidence; and

it is not reasonably practicable, having regard to the urgency of the case or the existence of exceptional circumstances, to make a written application for the issuing of the preservation of evidence direction applied for; and

on condition that the member of the law enforcement agency concerned must submit a written application to the magistrate or judge of the High Court concerned within 48 hours after the issuing of the preservation of evidence direction under subsection (3).

content.p: A preservation of evidence direction issued under subsection (3) must be in writing and must be transmitted electronically to the member of the law enforcement agency.

A magistrate or judge of the High Court who issued a direction under subsection (3) or, if he or she is not available, any other magistrate or judge of the High Court must, upon receipt of a written application submitted to him or her in terms of subsection (4)(b), reconsider that application whereupon he or she may confirm, amend or cancel that preservation of evidence direction.

section.heading: Access to data and receipt and forwarding of unsolicited information

blockList.listIntroduction: Any member of a law enforcement agency or an investigator may, without being specifically authorised thereto in terms of this Chapter—

item.p: accesspublic available data regardless of where the data is located geographically;

blockList.listIntroduction: access or receive non-public available data, regardless of where the data is located geographically, if the person who has the lawful authority to disclose the data, voluntarily—

item.p: in writing, consents to such accessing of data; or
provides the data to a member of a law enforcement agency or an investigator; or

blockList.listIntroduction: access any data, regardless of where the data is located geographically, if such data is lawfully—

item.p: accessible from; or

available to, a computer device, a computer network, a database, a critical database, an electronic communications network or a National Critical Information Infrastructure which is being accessed or seized in terms of section 29, 30, 31 or 32.

blockList.listIntroduction: The head of a law enforcement agency may, after obtaining the written approval of the National Director of Public Prosecutions as contemplated in subsection (3), forward any information obtained during any investigation to a law enforcement agency of a foreign State when that head of a law enforcement agency is of the opinion that the disclosure of such information may—

item.p: assist the foreign State in the initiation or carrying out of investigations regarding an offence committed within the jurisdiction of a foreign State; or

blockList.listIntroduction: lead to further cooperation with a foreign State to carry out an investigation regarding the commission or intended commission of—

item.p: an offence under Chapter 2 of this Act;
any other offence in terms of the laws of the Republic which may be committed or facilitated by means of an article; or

blockList.listIntroduction: an offence—

item.p: similar to those contemplated in Chapter 2 of this Act; or
any other offence substantially similar to an offence recognised in the Republic which is or was committed by means of, or facilitated by the use of an article, in a foreign State.

blockList.listIntroduction: The National Director of Public Prosecutions must consider a request by a head of a law enforcement agency in terms of subsection (2) and may only grant approval referred to in subsection (2) if he or she is satisfied that the forwarding of information —

item.p: will not affect any pending criminal proceedings or investigations adversely regarding criminal offences committed within the Republic; and
is in accordance with any applicable law of the Republic.

blockList.listIntroduction: A law enforcement agency may receive any information from a foreign State which will—

item.p: assist the law enforcement agency in the initiation or carrying out of investigations regarding an offence committed within the Republic; or

blockList.listIntroduction: lead to further cooperation with a foreign State to carry out an investigation regarding the commission or intended commission of—

item.p: an offence under Chapter 2 of this Act; or
any other offence in terms of the laws of the Republic which may be committed by means of or facilitated by, an article.

section.heading: Issuing of direction requesting foreign assistance and cooperation

blockList.listIntroduction: If it appears to a magistrate or judge of the High Court from information on oath or by way of affirmation that there are reasonable grounds for believing that an article necessary for the investigation or prosecution of—

item.p: an offence under Chapter 2 of this Act; or

blockList.listIntroduction: any other offence in terms of the laws of the Republic which may be committed or facilitated by means of an article, is in the possession of, under the control of or upon any person or in a container, upon or at any premises, vehicle, facility, ship, aircraft, computer device, computer network, database or any part of an electronic communications network within the area of jurisdiction of a foreign State, the magistrate or the judge may issue a direction in the prescribed form, in which assistance from that foreign State is sought in order to—

item.p: preserve an article; or
intercept or obtain and provide data, as is stated in the direction.

blockList.listIntroduction: A direction contemplated in subsection (1) must specify that—

item.p: there are reasonable grounds for believing that an offence contemplated in this Act has been committed in the Republic or that it is necessary to determine whether an offence has been committed;
an investigation in respect thereof is being conducted; and

for purposes of the investigation, it is necessary, in the interests of justice, that the article be preserved, or that data be intercepted or obtained and be provided by a person or authority in a foreign State.

blockList.listIntroduction: Subject to subsection (4), a direction must be sent to the National Director of Public Prosecutions for transmission to—

item.p: the court or tribunal specified in the direction;
the appropriate authority in the foreign State which is requested to provide assistance and cooperation; or
a designated 24/7 contact point in the foreign State which is requested to provide assistance and cooperation.

In a case of urgency a direction may be transmitted directly to the court or tribunal referred to in subsection (3)(a), exercising jurisdiction in the place where the article is to be preserved, or the data is to be intercepted or obtained and be provided, or to the appropriate government authority referred to in subsection (3)(b) or designated 24/7 contact point referred to in subsection (3)(c).

The National Director of Public Prosecutions must, as soon as practicable, be notified that a direction has been sent in the manner referred to in paragraph (a) and he or she must be furnished with a copy of such direction.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for the administration of justice must be notified that a direction has been sent as contemplated in subsection (3) or (4) and must be furnished with a copy of such direction.

section.heading: Foreign requests for assistance and cooperation

blockList.listIntroduction: A request by an authority, court or tribunal exercising jurisdiction in a foreign State for assistance in preserving an article or the interception or the obtaining and providing of data in the Republic for use by such foreign State must be submitted—
to the 24/7 point of contact established in terms of section 49 of this Act, which must submit it—

item.p: to the National Director of Public Prosecutions; or
in a case of urgency, to the designated judge;
to the National Director of Public Prosecutions; or
in a case of urgency, to the designated judge.

blockList.listIntroduction: Upon receipt of a request in terms of subsection (1)(a)(i) or (b), the National Director of Public Prosecutions must satisfy himself or herself—

item.p: that proceedings have been instituted in a court or tribunal exercising jurisdiction in the requesting foreign State; or

that there are reasonable grounds for believing that an offence has been committed in the requesting foreign State or that it is necessary to determine whether an offence has been so committed and that an investigation in respect thereof is being conducted in the requesting foreign State.

blockList.listIntroduction: Upon receipt of a request in terms of subsection (1)(a)(ii) or (c), the designated judge, must—
satisfy himself or herself—

item.p: that proceedings have been instituted in a court or tribunal exercising jurisdiction in the requesting foreign State; or

that there are reasonable grounds for believing that an offence has been committed in the requesting foreign State or that it is necessary to determine whether an offence has been so committed and that an investigation in respect thereof is being conducted in the requesting foreign State; and
obtain the recommendations of the National Director of Public Prosecutions on the request.

content.p: For purposes of subsection (2) and (3)(a), the National Director of Public Prosecutions or the designated judge may rely on a certificate purported to be issued by a competent authority in the foreign State concerned, stating the facts contemplated in the said subsections.

item.p: The National Director of Public Prosecutions must, if satisfied as contemplated in subsection (2), submit the request for assistance in preserving an article or intercepting or obtaining and providing data, together with his or her recommendations, to the Cabinet member responsible for the administration of justice, for his or her approval.

Upon being notified of the Cabinet member‟s approval the National Director of Public Prosecutions must forward the request contemplated in subsection (1)(a) or (b) to the designated judge, for consideration.

blockList.listIntroduction: Subject to subsection (7), the designated judge may on receipt of a request referred to—

item.p: in subsection (1)(a)(ii) or (c), subject to paragraph (b); or

blockList.listIntroduction: in subsection (5)(b), issue any order which he or she deems appropriate to ensure that the requested—

item.p: article is preserved for a period; or
data is intercepted or obtained and provided, as is specified in the request.

blockList.listIntroduction: The designated judge must, before any order as contemplated in paragraph (a) is issued, inform the Cabinet member responsible for the administration of justice, in writing of the—

item.p: fact that he or she intends to issue an order; and
reasons for such decision.

blockList.listIntroduction: The designated judge may only issue an order contemplated in subsection (6)(a), if—
on the facts alleged in the request, there are reasonable grounds to believe that—

item.p: an offence substantially similar to the offences contemplated in Chapter 2. of this Act, has been or is being or will probably be committed; or
any other offence substantially similar to an offence recognised in the Republic was committed by means of, or facilitated through the use of an article; and
that for purposes of the investigation it is necessary in the interests of justice that an article be preserve for a period or that data be intercepted or obtained and provided;

blockList.listIntroduction: the request clearly identifies—

item.p: the article that must be preserved;
the data which must be intercepted or obtained and be provided; and

blockList.listIntroduction: the person, entity or electronic communications service provider—

item.p: who or which is in possession of the article that must be preserved;
from whose facilities the data must be intercepted and provided; or
from whom the data must be obtained or provided;

blockList.listIntroduction: the request is, where applicable, in accordance with—

item.p: any treaty, convention or other international agreement to which that foreign state and the Republic are parties; or
any agreement with any foreign State entered into in terms of section 65 of this Act;
the order contemplated in subsection (6)(a) is in accordance with any applicable law of the Republic; and
that it will be in the interests of justice if the order contemplated in subsection 6(a) is made.

content.p: An order contemplated in subsection (6)(a) must be executed by a member of the South African Police Service referred to in section 33 of the South African Police Service Act, 1995 (Act No. 68 of 1995), who is specifically designated in writing by the National Commissioner to execute such orders.

section.heading: Complying with order of designated judge

content.p: A person or electronic communications service provider must immediately comply with an order of the designated judge issued in terms of section 46(6).

A person or electronic communications service provider to whom an order referred to in section 46(6) is addressed, may in writing apply to the designated judge for an amendment or the cancellation of the order concerned on the ground that he, she or it cannot timeously or in a reasonable fashion, comply with the order.

blockList.listIntroduction: The designated judge to whom an application is made in terms of subsection (2) must, as soon as possible after receipt thereof—

item.p: consider the application and may, for this purpose, order oral or written evidence to be adduced regarding any fact alleged in the application;
give a decision in respect of the application; and
if the application is successful, inform the National Director of Public Prosecutions of the outcome of the application.

blockList.listIntroduction: A person or an electronic communications service provider who—

item.p: fails to comply with an order referred to in section 46(6); or

makes a false statement in an application referred to in subsection (2), is guilty of an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding R5 million or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or to both such fine and imprisonment.

section.heading: Informing foreign State of outcome of request for assistance and cooperation and furnishing of data to foreign State

content.p: The National Director of Public Prosecutions must inform a foreign State of the outcome of its request for assistance and cooperation.

blockList.listIntroduction: Any data which is intercepted or obtained in terms of an order referred to in section 46(6) of this Act, must be—

item.p: provided to the 24/7 Point of Contact, established in terms of section 49 of this Act, for submission to an authority, court or tribunal of a foreign State, in an industry-standard format which ensures ease of access to the information and which guarantees the authenticity, integrity and reliability of the information; and

blockList.listIntroduction: accompanied by—

item.p: a copy of the order referred to in section 46(6); and

an affidavit in the prescribed form by the person or authorised representative of an electronic communications service provider, verifying the authenticity, integrity and reliability of the information that is furnished.

content.p: A person or electronic communications service provider must keep copies of any the information which is furnished to the 24/7 Point of Contact in terms of subsection (2)(a), for a period of three years, in a manner which will ensure the authenticity, integrity and reliability of the information.

The information referred to in subsection (2)(a), together with the copy of the order and affidavit referred to in subsection (2)(b), must be provided to the authority, court or tribunal exercising jurisdiction in a foreign State which requested the assistance in terms of section 46(1), in the manner agreed upon.

A person or electronic communications service provider who— (a) fails to comply with subsections (2) or (3); (b) makes a false statement in an affidavit referred to in subsection (2)(b)(ii), is guilty of an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine or imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or to both such fine and imprisonment.

section.heading: Establishment of 24/7 Point of Contact

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for policing must, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters—

item.p: establish an office to be known as the 24/7 Point of Contact for the Republic; and
equip, operate and maintain the 24/7 Point of Contact.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for policing exercises final responsibility over the administration and functioning of the 24/7 Point of Contact.

blockList.listIntroduction: The National Commissioner must appoint a member of the Service—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her technical knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 70. of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, as Director of the 24/7 Point of Contact.

The Director must exercise the powers and must perform the functions and carry out the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the National Commissioner or under this Act, subject to the control and directions of the National Commissioner.

blockList.listIntroduction: Whenever the Director is for any reason temporarily unable to exercise, perform and carry out his or her powers, functions and duties, the National Commissioner must appoint a member of the Service—

item.p: who on the grounds of his or her technical knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, as acting Director.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Director must, in the exercise of the powers, performance of the functions and carrying out of the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the National Commissioner or under this Act, be assisted, subject to his or her control and directions, by—

item.p: appropriately qualified members of the Service designated to the 24/7 Point of Contact and to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security;

blockList.listIntroduction: a member of the National Prosecuting Authority at the rank of at least DeputyDirector of Public Prosecutions— (aa) who has particular knowledge and skills in respect of any aspect dealt with in this Act;

item.p: who is seconded to the 24/7 Point of Contact to assist the Director; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State Security; and

blockList.listIntroduction: any person or entity—

item.p: who or which has particular knowledge and skills in respect of any aspect dealt with in this Act;
who or which is appointed to assist the Director from time to time; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State Security.

blockList.listIntroduction: In order to achieve the objects of this Act, the Director must—

item.p: carry out the administrative duties relating to the functioning of the 24/7 Point of Contact;
exercise control over the persons contemplated in subsection (3)(d);
manage and exercise administrative and technical control over the 24/7 Point of Contact;
regulate the procedure and determine the manner in which the provisions of this Act must be carried out by the 24/7 Point of Contact; and

co-ordinate the activities of the 24/7 Point of Contact with those of the Cyber Security Centre, the Government Security Incident Response teams, the Cyber Crime Response Centre, the Cyber Command, the Cyber Security Hub and the Private Sector Security Incident Response Teams.

The Director is, for the purposes of the exercising the powers, performing the functions and carrying out of the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the National Commissioner or under this Act, accountable to the National Commissioner regarding any matter relevant to, incidental to or which may impact on the objects and functions of the 24/7 Point of Contact as set out in subsection (4).

The Director must, on a monthly basis, or as the National Commissioner requires, submit a written report to the National Commissioner regarding any matter relevant to, incidental to or which may impact on the objects and functions of the 24/7 Point of Contact as set out in subsection (4).

The Director must, on a quarterly basis, or as the Chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee requires, submit a written report to the Cabinet member responsible for policing and the Chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee regarding any matter relating to this Act which the Director wishes to or may want to bring to the attention of the Cyber Response Committee.

blockList.listIntroduction: The 24/7 Point of Contact must operate on a twenty-four hour, seven-day-a-week basis, in order to ensure the provision of immediate expedited assistance for the purpose of proceedings or investigations regarding the commission or intended commission of—

item.p: an offence under Chapter 2 of this Act;
any other offence in terms of the laws of the Republic which may be committed or facilitated by means of an article; or

blockList.listIntroduction: an offence—

item.p: similar to those contemplated in Chapter 2 of this Act; or
any other offence substantially similar to an offence recognised in the Republic which is or was committed by means of, or facilitated by the use of an article, in a foreign State.

blockList.listIntroduction: The assistance contemplated in subsection (4)(a), includes—

item.p: the provision of technical advice and assistance;
the facilitation or provision of assistance regarding anything which is authorised under Chapter 4 of this Act;
the provision of legal information;
the identification and location of an article;
the identification and location of a suspect; and
cooperation with appropriate authorities of a foreign State.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for policing may, after consultation with the Cyber Response Committee, make regulations to further—

item.p: regulate any aspect provided for in subsection (4);
impose additional duties on the 24/7 Point of Contact; and
regulate any aspect which is necessary or expedient for the proper implementation of this section.

The Cabinet member responsible for policing must, at the end of each financial year, submit a report to Chairperson of the Joint Standing Committee on Intelligence established by section 2 of the Intelligence Services Control Act, 1994 (Act 40 of 1994), on the functions and activities of the 24/7 Point of Contact.

blockList.listIntroduction: The report contemplated in paragraph (a) must include—

item.p: the number of matters in which technical advice and assistance were provided to a foreign State; and
the number of matters in which technical advice and assistance were received from a foreign State.

chapter.heading: Structures to deal with cyber security

section.heading: Definitions and interpretation

blockList.listIntroduction: For purposes of this Chapter, unless the context indicates otherwise—

item.p: "Head of a Department" means the incumbent of a post mentioned in Column 2 of Schedule 1, 2 or 3 to the Public Service Act, 1994 (Proclamation 103 of 3 June 1994), and includes any employee acting in such post; and

blockList.listIntroduction: "representative Department" means—

item.p: the Department of Correctional Services;
the Department of Defence;
the Department of Home Affairs;
the Department of Justice and Constitutional Development;
the National Prosecuting Authority;
the South African Police Service;
the State Security Agency;
the Department of Finance;

the Financial Intelligence Centre, established by section 2 of the Financial Intelligence Centre Act, 2001 (Act No. 38 of 2001); (x) the State Information Technology Agency, established in terms of section 2 of the State Information Technology Agency Act, 1998 (Act No. 88 of 1998); (xi) the Department of Science and Technology; and
any other Department or public entity which is requested, in writing, by the Chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee to assist the Committee.

section.heading: Cyber Response Committee

content.p: The Cyber Response Committee is hereby established.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cyber Response Committee consists of—

item.p: a chairperson who is the Director-General: State Security;

blockList.listIntroduction: members who are the Heads of the representative Departments and their nominees who must be officials—

item.p: at the rank of at least a chief director or equivalent, of a representative Department, who are specifically nominated by a Head of that representative Department to serve on the Cyber Response Committee; and
to whom a security clearance certificate has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994); and

any person who has particular knowledge and skills in respect of any aspect dealt with in this Act and who is, from time to time, requested, in writing, by the Chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee to assist the Committee.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for State security must appoint a member to act as chairperson whenever the chairperson is absent from the Republic or from duty, or for any reason, is temporarily unable to carry out the responsibilities as chairperson.

The work incidental to the performance of the functions of the Cyber Response Committee must be performed by a secretariat, consisting of designated administrative personnel of the State Security Agency allocated to the Cyber Security Centre established in terms of section 52 of this Act.
The chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee must determine the scheduled time and place of meetings of the Committee and make this known to the other members of the Committee.

blockList.listIntroduction: The objects and functions of the Cyber Response Committee are to—

item.p: implement Government policy relating to cybersecurity;
identify and prioritise areas of intervention;
coordinate cybersecurity activities and be a central point of contact on all cybersecurity matters pertinent to national security;
identify and prioritise areas of intervention and promote focussed attention and guidance where required regarding cybersecurity related threats and incidents;

promote, guide and coordinate activities aimed at improving cybersecurity measures by all role players, which includes the strengthening of intelligence collection and improved State capacity to investigate, prosecute and combat cybercrime and to deal with cyber threats;

oversee and guide the functioning of the 24/7 Point of Contact, the Cyber Security Centre, the Government Security Incident Response Teams, the Cyber Crime Response Centre, the Cyber Command, the Cyber Security Hub and the Private Sector Security Incident Response Teams established in the Republic;

blockList.listIntroduction: promote and provide guidance in respect of the development and implementation of—

item.p: the National Critical Information Infrastructure Plan;
any situational analysis and awareness campaigns concerning the risk environment of South African cyberspace;
a cybersecurity culture and compliance with minimum security standards;
public-private partnerships and national and regional action plans in line with Government policy;
appropriate technical and operational cybersecurity standards;
cybersecurity training, education, research and development and skills development programmes; and
international cooperation initiatives;
facilitate interaction on cyber security, both nationally and internationally and to develop policy guidelines in order to give effect to such interaction;
facilitate the establishment of sector, regional and continental Computer Security Incident Response Teams; and
establish and promote a comprehensive legal framework governing cyber-related matters.

blockList.listIntroduction: No person referred to in subsection (2), may disclose any confidential information or document obtained by that person in the performance of his or her functions in terms of this Act, except—

item.p: to the extent to which it may be necessary for the proper administration of any provision of this Act;
to any person who of necessity requires it for the performance of any function in terms of this Act;
when required to do so by order of a court of law; or
with the written permission of the Cyber Response Committee.

Any person who contravenes a provision of paragraph (a) is guilty of an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine, or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding 2 years or to both such fine and imprisonment.

blockList.listIntroduction: Any person referred to in subsection (2)(c), must, before assisting the Cyber Security Committee, make and subscribe to an affirmation of secrecy in the following form: 'I, .............................................. solemnly declare:

item.p: I have taken cognizance of the provisions of section 51(7) of the Cyber Crimes and Cybersecurity Act, .... (Act No. of ............).

I understand that I may not disclose any information or document, or the contents thereof, of whatever nature that comes to my knowledge or into my possession in consequence of my performance of any function in terms of the Cyber Crimes and Cybersecurity Act, .... (Act No. of ............), whether verbal or in writing, to any unauthorized person without the prior written approval of the Chairperson of the Cyber Security Committee.
I am fully aware of the serious consequences which may follow any breach or contravention of the above-mentioned provisions. .................................... (Signature)'.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for State security may, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters, make regulations regarding travelling, subsistence, remuneration and other expenses and allowances payable to a person referred to in subsection (2)(c).
The Cabinet member responsible for State security must oversee and exercise control over the performance of the functions of the Cyber Response Committee.

The Cabinet member responsible for State security must, at the end of each financial year, submit a report to Chairperson of the Joint Standing Committee on Intelligence established by section 2 of the Intelligence Services Control Act, 1994 (Act 40 of 1994), regarding progress that has been made towards achieving the objects and functions of the Cyber Response Committee.

section.heading: Cyber Security Centre

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for State security must, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters—

item.p: establish a Cyber Security Centre; and
equip, operate and maintain the Cyber Security Centre.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for State security exercises final responsibility over the administration and functioning of the Cyber Security Centre.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for State security must enter into service level agreements with—

item.p: the Head of a department; and
any entity or institution, in respect of the provision of services by the Cyber Security Centre.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for State security must appoint a person from the State Security Agency—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her technical knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, as Director of the Cyber Security Centre.

The Director must exercise the powers and must perform the functions and carry out the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the Cabinet member responsible for State security or under this Act, subject to the control and directions of the Cabinet member.

blockList.listIntroduction: Whenever the Director is for any reason temporarily unable to exercise, perform or carry out his or her powers, functions and duties, the Cabinet member responsible for State security must appoint a person from the State Security Agency—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, as acting Director.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Director must, in the exercise of the powers, performance of the functions and carrying out of the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the Cabinet member or under this Act, be assisted, subject to his or her control and directions, by—

item.p: members of the State Security Agency allocated to the Cyber Security Centre to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security;

blockList.listIntroduction: any person or a entity—

item.p: who or which has particular knowledge and skills in respect of any aspect dealt with in this Act;
who or which is, from time to time, appointed to assist the Director; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994, to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State Security must—

blockList.listIntroduction: In order to achieve the objects of this Act, the Director

item.p: carry out the administrative duties relating to the functioning of the Cyber Security Centre;

exercise control over the members of the State Security Agency allocated to the Cyber Security Centre, Government Security Incident Response Teams or persons or entities contemplated in subsection (4)(d)(ii);
manage, and exercise administrative and technical control over the Cyber Security Centre and Government Security Incident Response Teams;
regulate the procedure and determine the manner in which the provisions of this Act must be carried out by Cyber Security Centre and Government Security Incident Response Teams; and

co-ordinate the activities of the Cyber Security Centre and Government Security Incident Response teams with those of the 24/7 Point of Contact, the National Cybercrime Centre, the Cyber Command, the Cyber Security Hub and the Private Sector Security Incident Response Teams.

The Director is, for the purposes of exercising the powers, performing the functions and carrying out the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the Cabinet member responsible for State Security or under this Act, accountable to the Cabinet member.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Director must, on a quarterly basis, or as the Chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee requires, submit a written report to the Cabinet member responsible for State security and the Chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee regarding—

item.p: cyber security-related threats, any measures implemented to address such cyber security-related threats and shortcomings in addressing such cyber security related threats;
any matter relevant to, incidental to or which may impact on the objects and functions of the Cyber Security Centre as set out in subsection (5); and
any other matter relating to this Act which the Director wishes to or may want to bring to the attention of the Cyber Response Committee.

blockList.listIntroduction: The objects and functions of the Cyber Security Centre are to—

item.p: facilitate the operational coordination of cyber security incident response activities regarding national intelligence;
develop measures to deal with cyber security matters impacting on national security;

facilitate the analysis of cyber security incidents, trends, vulnerabilities, information-sharing, technology exchange on national security and threats in order to improve technical response coordination;
provide guidance to and facilitate the identification, protection and securing of National Critical Information Infrastructures;

ensure the assessment and testing of National Critical Information Infrastructures, including vulnerability assessments, threat and risk assessments and penetration testing, on the written request of the Director-General: State Security;

provide coordination and guidance regarding corporate security and policy development, governance, risk management and compliance, identity and security management, security information and event management and cyber forensics;
develop response protocols in order to guide coordinated responses to cyber security incidents and interaction with the various stakeholders;
ensure the conducting of cyber security audits, assessments and readiness exercises and provide advice on the development of national response plans;
act as a point of contact regarding matters relating to State security; and
provide the secretarial services required in relation to the Cyber Response Committee.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet Member responsible for State security may make regulations to further—

item.p: regulate any aspect provided for in subsection (5);
impose additional duties upon the Cyber Security Centre; and
regulate any aspect which is necessary or expedient for the proper implementation of this section.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for State security may, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters, make regulations regarding travelling, subsistence, remuneration and other expenses and allowances payable to a person or entity referred to in subsection (4)(d)(ii).

The Cabinet member responsible for State security must, at the end of each financial year, submit a report to Chairperson of the Joint Standing Committee on Intelligence established by section 2 of the Intelligence Services Control Act, 1994 (Act 40 of 1994), on the functions of the Cyber Security Centre.

section.heading: Government Security Incident Response Teams

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for State security must, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters—

item.p: establish one or more Government Security Incident Response Teams; and
equip, operate and maintain the Government Security Incident Response Teams.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for State security exercises final responsibility over the administration and functioning of the Government Security Incident Response Teams.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for State security must enter into service level agreements with—

item.p: the Head of a department; and
any entity or institution, in respect of the provision of services by the Government Security Incident Response Teams.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Director-General: State Security must, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for State security, appoint a person from the State Security Agency—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, as head for each Government Security Incident Response Team established under this section.

The Head referred to in this section must exercise the powers and perform the functions and carry out the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the Director: Cyber Security Centre or under this Act, subject to the control and directions of the Director: Cyber Security Centre.

blockList.listIntroduction: Whenever a Head of a Government Security Incident Response Team is, for any reason, temporarily unable to exercise, perform or carry out his or her powers, functions and duties, the Director-General: State Security must, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for State security, appoint a person from the State Security Agency—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, as acting Head.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Head of a Government Security Incident Response Team must, in the exercise of the powers, performance of the functions and carrying out of the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the Director: Cyber Security Centre or under this Act, be assisted, subject to his or her control and directions, by—

item.p: members of the State Security Agency, to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, allocated to the Government Security Incident Response Team;

blockList.listIntroduction: any person or a entity—

item.p: who or which has particular knowledge and skills in respect of any aspect dealt with in this Act;
who or which is, from time to time, appointed to assist the Head; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994, to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security.

blockList.listIntroduction: In order to achieve the objects of this Act, a Head referred to in this section must—

item.p: carry out the administrative duties relating to the functioning of the Government Security Incident Response Team;
exercise control over the members of the State Security Agency allocated to the Government Security Incident Response Team or persons or entities contemplated in subsection (4)(d)(ii);
manage and exercise administrative and technical control over the Government Security Incident Response Team;
regulate the procedure and determine the manner in which the provisions of this Act must be carried out by the Government Security Incident Response Team; and

co-ordinate the activities of the Government Security Incident Response Team with those of the 24/7 Point of Contact, other Government Security Incident Response Teams, the Cyber Security Centre, the National Cybercrime Centre, the Cyber Command, the Cyber Security Hub and Private Sector Security Incident Response Teams.

The Head referred to in this section is, for the purposes of exercising the powers, performing the functions and carrying out of the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the Director: Cyber Security Centre or under this Act, accountable to the Director: Cyber Security Centre.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Head referred to in this section must, on a monthly basis, or as the Director: Cyber Security Centre requires, submit a written report to the Director: Cyber Security Centre regarding —

item.p: cyber security-related threats and measures implemented in order to address such cyber security-related threats and shortcomings in addressing such cyber security-related threats;
any matter relevant to, incidental to or which may impact on the objects and functions of the Government Security Incident Response Team as set out in subsection (5); and
any other matter relating to this Act which the Head wishes to or may want to bring to the attention of the Director: Cyber Security Centre or Cyber Response Committee.

blockList.listIntroduction: The objects and functions of a Government Security Incident Response Team are to—

item.p: develop or acquire and implement measures to deal with cyber security matters impacting on national intelligence and national security;
protect and secure National Critical Information Infrastructures;

implement measures, on the written request of the Director-General: State Security, in order to assess and test National Critical Information Infrastructures, including vulnerability assessments, threat and risk assessments and penetration testing;

blockList.listIntroduction: provide a reactive service to the State which includes—

item.p: responding to alerts and warnings;

blockList.listIntroduction: handling incidents by—

item.p: incident analysis;
providing incident responses on site;
providing incident response support; and
incident response coordination;

blockList.listIntroduction: vulnerability handling by— (aa) analysing vulnerabilities;

item.p: mitigating the effect of a vulnerability or repairing a vulnerability; and
coordinating responses to vulnerabilities; and

blockList.listIntroduction: artifact handling by— (aa) analysing artifacts;

item.p: responding to artifacts; and
artifact response coordination;

blockList.listIntroduction: provide a proactive service to the State which includes—

item.p: intrusion alerts, vulnerability warnings, security advice and other similar announcements;
technical analysis of software, malware, intruder activities and related trends in order to help identify future threats and vulnerabilities;
the furnishing of security audits and assessments;
the configuration and maintenance of equipment, software, hardware, configurations and infrastructure;
the development of security tools;
the provision of an intrusion detection service; and
the dissemination of security-related information to Government Departments; and

blockList.listIntroduction: provide security quality management services to the State which includes—

item.p: a risk analysis service;
a continuity of service and disaster recovery planning service;
a security consulting service; and
a product certification service.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet Member responsible for State security may, after consultation with the Cyber Response Committee, make regulations to further—

item.p: regulate any aspect provided for in subsection (5);
impose additional duties upon Government Security Incident Response Teams; and
regulate any aspect which is necessary or expedient for the proper implementation of this section.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for State security may, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters, make regulations regarding travelling, subsistence, remuneration and other expenses and allowances payable to a person or entity referred to in subsection (4)(d)(ii).

The Cabinet member responsible for State security must, at the end of each financial year, submit a report to Chairperson of the Joint Standing Committee on Intelligence established by section 2 of the Intelligence Services Control Act, 1994 (Act 40 of 1994), on the functions of the Government Security Incident Response Teams.

section.heading: National Cybercrime Centre

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for policing must, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters—

item.p: establish a National Cybercrime Centre; and
equip, operate and maintain the National Cybercrime Centre.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for policing exercises final responsibility over the administration and functioning of the National Cybercrime Centre.

blockList.listIntroduction: The National Commissioner must appoint a member from the Service—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, as Director of the National Cybercrime Centre.

The Director must exercise the powers and perform the functions and carry out the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the National Commissioner or under this Act, subject to the control and directions of the National Commissioner.

blockList.listIntroduction: Whenever the Director is, for any reason, temporarily unable to exercise, perform or carry out his or her powers, functions and duties, the National Commissioner must appoint a person from the Service—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, as acting Director.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Director must, in exercising the powers and performing the functions and carrying out the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the National Commissioner or under this Act, be assisted, subject to his or her control and directions, by—

item.p: appropriately qualified members of the Service, to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, allocated to the National Cybercrime Centre;

blockList.listIntroduction: any person or an entity—

item.p: who or which has particular knowledge and skills in respect of any aspect dealt with in this Act;
who or which is, from time to time, appointed to assist the Director; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994, to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security.

blockList.listIntroduction: In order to achieve the objects of this Act, the Director must—

item.p: carry out the administrative duties relating to the functioning of the National Cybercrime Centre;
exercise control over the members of the Service allocated to the National Cybercrime Centre or persons or entities contemplated in paragraph (d)(ii);
manage and exercise administrative and technical control over the National Cybercrime Centre;
regulate the procedure and determine the manner in which the provisions of this Act must be carried out by the National Cybercrime Centre;

co-ordinate the activities of the National Cybercrime Centre with those of the 24/7 Point of Contact, the Cyber Security Centre, the Government Security Incident Response Teams, the Cyber Command, the Cybersecurity Hub and the Private Sector Security Incident Response Teams; and
develop and implement cyber security policies and strategies to investigate and combat cybercrime.

The Director is, for the purposes of exercising the powers, performing the functions and carrying out of the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the National Commissioner or under this Act, accountable to the National Commissioner.

The Director must, on a monthly basis, or as the National Commissioner requires, submit a written report to the National Commissioner regarding any matter relevant to, incidental to or which may impact on the objects and functions of the National Cybercrime Centre as are set out in subsection (4).

blockList.listIntroduction: The Director must, on a quarterly basis, or as the Chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee requires, submit a written report to the Cabinet member responsible for policing and the Chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee regarding—

item.p: cyber security-related threats impacting on law enforcement, any measures implemented to address such cyber security-related threats and shortcomings in addressing such cyber security-related threats;
cyber crime trends;
successes and shortcomings in investigative measures in order to investigate cybercrime;
successes and shortcomings in international cooperation in the investigation of cybercrime;
any matter relevant to, incidental to or which may impact on the objects and functions of the National Cybercrime Centre as set out in subsection (4); and
any other matter relating to this Act which the Director wishes to or may want to bring to the attention of the Cyber Response Committee.

blockList.listIntroduction: The objects and functions of the National Cybercrime Centre are to—

item.p: facilitate the operational coordination of cyber security incident response activities with reference to the prevention, combating and investigation of crime in order to maintain public order, to secure the inhabitants of the Republic and their property and to uphold and enforce the laws of the Republic;
develop measures in order to deal with cyber security matters impacting on law enforcement;

facilitate the analysis of cyber security incidents, trends, vulnerabilities, information-sharing, technology exchange on law enforcement and threats in order to improve technical response coordination;

provide coordination and guidance regarding corporate security and policy development, governance, risk management and compliance, identity and security management, security information and events management;
establish, develop and maintain an adequate cyber forensics capacity;
develop response protocols in order to guide coordinated responses to cyber security incidents and interact with the various stakeholders;
develop and maintain cross-border law enforcement cooperation in respect of cybercrime;
promote, establish and maintain public-private cooperation in order to fight cybercrime;
promote, establish and maintain international cooperation in order to fight cybercrime; and
develop capacity and implement measures in order to impede and neutralize cyber security-related incidents and threats.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet Member responsible for policing may, after consultation with the Cyber Response Committee, make regulations to further—

item.p: regulate any aspect provided for in subsection (4);
impose additional duties upon the National Cybercrime Centre; and
regulate any aspect which is necessary or expedient for the proper implementation of this section.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for policing may, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters, make regulations regarding travelling, subsistence, remuneration and other expenses and allowances payable to a person or entity referred to in subsection (3)(d)(ii).

The Cabinet member responsible for policing must, at the end of each financial year, submit a report to Parliament regarding progress that has been made towards achieving the objects and functions of the National Cybercrime Centre.

section.heading: Cyber Command

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for defence must, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters—

item.p: establish a Cyber Command as part of the Intelligence Division of the South African National Defence Force contemplated in section 33 of the Defence Act, 2002 (Act 42 of 2002); and
equip, operate and maintain the Cyber Command.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for defence exercises final responsibility over the administration and functioning of the Cyber Command.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Chief of the South African National Defence Force must appoint a member or employee from the South African National Defence Force—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her technical knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and
to whom a security clearance has been issued in terms of section 37 of the Defence Act, 2002 (Act No. 42 of 2002), as General Officer Commanding of the Cyber Command.

The General Officer Commanding must exercise the powers and perform the functions and carry out the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the Chief of the South African National Defence Force or under this Act, subject to the control and directions of the Chief of the South African National Defence Force.

blockList.listIntroduction: Whenever the General Officer Commanding is for any reason temporarily unable to exercise, perform and carry out his or her powers, functions and duties, the Chief of the South African National Defence Force must appoint a member or employee from the South African National Defence Force—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her technical knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and
to whom a security clearance has been issued in terms of section 37 of the Defence Act, 2002 (Act No. 42 of 2002), as acting General Officer Commanding.

blockList.listIntroduction: The General Officer Commanding must, in exercising the powers, performing the functions and carrying out of the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the Chief of the South African National Defence Force or under this Act, be assisted, subject to his or her control and directions, by—

item.p: members and employees of the South African National Defence Force, to whom a security clearance has been issued in terms of section 37 of the Defence Act, 2002 (Act No. 42 of 2002);

blockList.listIntroduction: any person or an entity—

item.p: who or which has particular knowledge and skills in respect of any aspect dealt with in this Act;
who or which is, from time to time, appointed to assist the General Officer Commanding; and
to whom a security clearance has been issued in terms of section 37 of the Defence Act, 2002 (Act No. 42 of 2002).

blockList.listIntroduction: In order to achieve the objects of this Act, the General Officer Commanding must—

item.p: carry out the administrative duties relating to the functioning of the Cyber Command;
exercise control over the members and employees of the Defence Force or persons or entities contemplated in subsection (3)(d)(ii);
manage and exercise administrative and technical control over the Cyber Command;
regulate the procedure and determine the manner in which the provisions of this Act must be carried out by Cyber Command;

co-ordinate the activities of the Cyber Command with those of the 24/7 Point of Contact, the Cyber Security Centre, the Government Security Incident Response Teams, the National Cybercrime Centre, the Cyber Security Hub and the Private Sector Security Incident Response Teams.

The General Officer Commanding is, for the purposes of exercising the powers, performing of the functions and carrying out of the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the the Chief of the South African National Defence Force or under this Act, accountable to the Chief of the South African National Defence Force.

The General Officer Commanding must, on a monthly basis, or as the Chief of the South African National Defence Force requires, submit a written report to the Chief of the South African National Defence Force regarding any matter relevant to, incidental to, or which may impact on the objects and functions of the Cyber Command as set out in subsection (4).

blockList.listIntroduction: The General Officer Commanding must, on a quarterly basis, or as the Chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee requires, submit a written report to the Cabinet member responsible for defence and the Chairperson of the Cyber Response Committee regarding—

item.p: cyber security-related threats, any measures implemented to address such cyber security-related threats and shortcomings in addressing such cyber securityrelated threats which may impact on the defence of the Republic;
any matter relevant to, incidental to or which may impact on the objects and functions of the Cyber Command as set out in subsection (4); or
any other matter relating to this Act which the General Officer Commanding wishes to or may want to bring to the attention of the Cyber Response Committee.

blockList.listIntroduction: The objects and functions of the Cyber Command are to—

item.p: facilitate the operational coordination of cyber security incident response activities regarding national defence;
develop measures to deal with cyber security matters impacting on national defence;

facilitate the analysis of cyber security incidents, trends, vulnerabilities, information-sharing, technology exchange and threats on national defence in order to improve technical response coordination;
provide guidance to and facilitate the identification, protection and securing of National Critical Information Infrastructures relevant to national defence;

ensure, on the written command of the Chief of the South African National Defence Force, regular assessments and testing of National Critical Information Infrastructures relevant to national defence, including vulnerability assessments, threat and risk assessments and penetration testing;
ensure the conducting of cyber security audits, assessments and readiness exercises and provide advice on the development of national response plans in so far as they relate to national defence;
act as a point of contact regarding matters relating to national defence; and
coordinate and implement cyber offensive and defensive measures as part of its defence mandate.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet Member responsible for defence may, after consultation with the Cyber Response Committee, make regulations to further—

item.p: regulate any aspect provided for in subsection (4); (b) impose additional duties upon the Cyber Command; and
regulate any aspect which it is necessary or expedient for the proper implementation of this section.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for defence may, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national finance matters, make regulations regarding travelling, subsistence, remuneration and other expenses and allowances payable to a person or entity referred to in subsection (3)(d)(ii).

The Cabinet member responsible for defence must, at the end of each financial year, submit a report to Chairperson of the Joint Standing Committee on Defence of Parliament, on the functions of the Cyber Command.

section.heading: Cyber Security Hub

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for telecommunications and postal services must, in consultation with the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters, —

item.p: establish a Cyber Security Hub; and
equip, operate and maintain the Cyber Security Hub.

content.p: The Cabinet member responsible for telecommunications and postal services exercises final responsibility over the administration and functioning of the Cyber Security Hub.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for telecommunications and postal services must enter into service level agreements with—

item.p: the Heads of departments; and
any public or private entity or institution, in respect of the provision of services by the Cyber Security Hub.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Cabinet member responsible for telecommunications and postal services must appoint a person—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her technical knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person,

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, as Director of the Cyber Security Hub.

The Director must exercise the powers and perform the functions and carry out the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the Cabinet member responsible for telecommunications and postal services or under this Act, subject to the control and directions of the Cabinet member.

blockList.listIntroduction: Whenever the Director is for any reason temporarily unable to exercise, perform or carry out his or her powers, functions and duties, the Cabinet member responsible for telecommunications and postal services must, appoint a person—

item.p: who, on the grounds of his or her knowledge and experience, is a suitable and qualified person; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, as acting Director.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Director must, in exercising the powers, performing the functions and carrying out the duties conferred upon, assigned to or imposed upon him or her by the Minister or under this Act, be assisted, subject to his or her control and directions, by—

item.p: officials or employees of the Department of Telecommunications and Postal Services, to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, allocated to the Cyber Security Hub;

members of the law enforcement agencies, to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994 (Act No. 39 of 1994), to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security, seconded to the Cyber Security Hub; and

blockList.listIntroduction: any person or a entity—

item.p: who or which has particular knowledge and skills in respect of any aspect dealt with in this Act; and
who or which is, from time to time, appointed to assist the Director; and

to whom a security clearance has been issued by the State Security Agency in terms of section 2A of the National Strategic Intelligence Act, 1994, to the satisfaction of the Cabinet member responsible for State security.

blockList.listIntroduction: In order to achieve the objects of this Act, the Director must—

item.p: carry out the administrative duties relating to the functioning of the Cyber Security Hub;
exercise control over the officials or employees, members and persons and entities contemplated in subsection (4)(d);
